data.title: Historically, men translated the Odyssey. Hereâ€™s what happened when a woman took the job.
data.meta_description: â€œTell me about a complicated man.â€ So begins Emily Wilsonâ€™s new translation, which reveals how the ancient story is relevant today.
data.text:
The Odyssey is about a man. It says so right at the beginning â€” in Robert Faglesâ€™s 1996 translation, for example, the poem opens with the line, â€œSing to me of the man, Muse, the man of twists and turns.â€

In the course of the poem, that man plots his return home after fighting the Trojan War, slaughters the suitors vying to marry his wife Penelope, and reestablishes himself as the head of his household.

But the Odyssey is also about other people: Penelope, the nymph Calypso, the witch Circe, the princess Nausicaa; Odysseusâ€™s many shipmates who died before they could make it home; the countless slaves in Odysseusâ€™s house, many of whom are never named.

Emily Wilson, the first woman to translate the Odyssey into English, is as concerned with these surrounding characters as she is with Odysseus himself. Written in plain, contemporary language and released earlier this month to much fanfare, her translation lays bare some of the inequalities between characters that other translations have elided. It offers not just a new version of the poem, but a new way of thinking about it in the context of gender and power relationships today. As Wilson puts it, â€œthe question of who matters is actually central to what the text is about.â€

Why it matters for a woman to translate the Odyssey

Composed around the 8th century BC, the Odyssey is one of the oldest works of literature typically read by an American audience; for comparison, itâ€™s almost 2,000 years older than Beowulf. While the Iliad tells the story of the Trojan War, the Odyssey picks up after the war is over, when Odysseus, the king of Ithaca, is trying to make his way home.

Both poems are traditionally attributed to the Greek poet Homer, but since they almost certainly originated as oral performances and not written texts, itâ€™s hard to tell whether a single person composed them, or whether they are the result of many different creators and performers refining and contributing to a story over a period of time. (The introduction to Wilsonâ€™s translation includes a longer discussion of the question of who â€œHomerâ€ was.)

Wilson, a professor of classical studies at the University of Pennsylvania, has also translated plays by the ancient Greek playwright Euripides and the Roman philosopher Seneca. Her translation of the Odyssey is one of many in English (though the others have been by men), including versions by Fagles, Robert Fitzgerald, Richmond Lattimore, and more. Translating the long-dead language Homer used â€” a variant of ancient Greek called Homeric Greek â€” into contemporary English is no easy task, and translators bring their own skills, opinions, and stylistic sensibilities to the text. The result is that every translation is different, almost a new poem in itself.

A battlefield epic, the Iliad has very few major female characters. The Odyssey, however, devotes significant time to the life (and even the dreams) of Penelope. Circe, Calypso, and the goddess Athena all play important roles. This was one of the reasons I was drawn to the Odyssey as a teenager, and why Iâ€™ve returned to it many times over the years.

But the Odyssey is hardly a feminist text. Odysseus may have trouble getting home, but at least he gets to travel the world and have sex with beautiful women like Calypso and Circe. Penelope, meanwhile, has to wait around while boorish suitors drink and carouse in her familyâ€™s home, pressuring her to marry one of them. To buy time, she says she canâ€™t marry until she finishes weaving a funeral shroud for her father-in-law, but every night she undoes the dayâ€™s work, making the task last as long as she can. â€œHis work always gets him somewhere,â€ Wilson told me. â€œHer work is all about undoing. Itâ€™s all about hiding herself, hiding her desires, and creating something whose only purpose is to get nowhere.â€

Some feminist readings of the Odyssey have tried to cast Penelope as heroic in her own way, sometimes by comparing her to Odysseus. â€œI think thereâ€™s so many things wrong with that,â€ Wilson said. â€œSheâ€™s constantly still being judged by, is she like him.â€ Whatâ€™s more, the heroic-Penelope reading focuses on a wealthy woman at the expense of the many enslaved women in the poem, some of whom meet an untimely and brutal end. When Odysseus returns home and kills all the suitors, he also tells his son Telemachus to kill the slave women who had sex with (or were raped by) the suitors. â€œHack at them with long swords, eradicate / all life from them,â€ Odysseus says in Wilsonâ€™s translation. â€œThey will forget the things / the suitors made them do with them in secret.â€

As a woman, Wilson believes she comes to the Odyssey with a different perspective than translators who have gone before her. â€œFemale translators often stand at a critical distance when approaching authors who are not only male, but also deeply embedded in a canon that has for many centuries been imagined as belonging to men,â€ she wrote in a recent essay at the Guardian. She called translating Homer as a woman an experience of â€œintimate alienation.â€

â€œEarlier translators are not as uncomfortable with the text as I am,â€ she explained to me, â€œand I like that Iâ€™m uncomfortable.â€ Part of her goal with the translation was to make readers uncomfortable too â€” with the fact that Odysseus owns slaves, and with the inequities in his marriage to Penelope. Making these aspects of the poem visible, rather than glossing over them, â€œmakes it a more interesting text,â€ she said.

Wilsonâ€™s translation is different from its predecessors in subtle â€” and not so subtle â€” ways

Part of the way Wilson challenges previous readings of the Odyssey is with style. Her translation made a splash months before it was published, when an excerpt ran in the summer 2017 issue of the Paris Review. I and other Odyssey fans were excited by Wilsonâ€™s opening line: â€œTell me about a complicated man.â€ In its matter-of-fact language, itâ€™s worlds different from Faglesâ€™s â€œSing to me of the man, Muse,â€ or Robert Fitzgeraldâ€™s 1961 version, â€œSing in me, Muse, and through me tell the story / of that man skilled in all ways of contending.â€ Wilson chose to use plain, relatively contemporary language in part to â€œinvite readers to respond more actively with the text,â€ she writes in a translatorâ€™s note. â€œImpressive displays of rhetoric and linguistic force are a good way to seem important and invite a particular kind of admiration, but they tend to silence dissent and discourage deeper modes of engagement.â€

â€œThereâ€™s an idea that Homer has to sound heroic and ancient,â€ Wilson told me, but that idea comes with a value system attached, one that includes â€œendorsing this very hierarchical kind of society as if thatâ€™s what heroism is.â€ Telling the story in plainer language allows readers to see Odysseus and his society in another light.

There are flashes of beauty in Wilsonâ€™s Odyssey. â€œThe early Dawn was born,â€ she writes in Book 2; â€œher fingers bloomed.â€ Of the forest on Calypsoâ€™s island, where many birds nest, she writes, â€œIt was full of wings.â€ But throughout the book, thereâ€™s a frankness to Wilsonâ€™s language around work and the people who do it. Of Eurymedusa, a slave in the house of princess Nausicaa, she writes, â€œShe used to babysit young Nausicaa / and now she lit her fire and cooked her meal.â€

The slaves in older translations of the Odyssey do not â€œbabysitâ€ â€” often, theyâ€™re not identified as slaves at all. Fagles, for instance, calls Eurymedusa a â€œchambermaid.â€ Fitzgerald calls her a â€œnurse.â€ â€œIt sort of stuns me when I look at other translations,â€ Wilson said, â€œhow much work seems to go into making slavery invisible.â€

Wilson, by contrast, uses the word â€œslaveâ€ for Eurymedusa and many other enslaved characters, even when the original uses a more specific term. The Homeric Greek dmoe, or â€œfemale-house-slave,â€ Wilson writes in her translatorâ€™s note, could be translated as â€œmaidâ€ or â€œdomestic servant,â€ but those terms would imply that the woman was free. â€œThe need to acknowledge the fact and the horror of slavery,â€ she writes, â€œand to mark the fact that the idealized society depicted in the poem is one where slavery is shockingly taken for granted, seems to me to outweigh the need to specify, in every instance, the type of slave.â€

While Wilsonâ€™s language is often plain, itâ€™s also carefully chosen. She told Wyatt Mason at the New York Times magazine she could have begun the poem with the line â€œTell me about a straying husband,â€ an even more radical choice that would still have been â€œa viable translation.â€ But, she said, â€œit would give an entirely different perspective and an entirely different setup for the poem.â€ She spoke, Mason noted, with â€œthe firmness of someone making hard choices she believes in.â€

Those choices show up clearly in her treatment of Penelope. Penelope is a frustrating character â€” itâ€™s not entirely clear why she doesnâ€™t simply send the suitors away or marry one of them, and the poem offers limited access to her thoughts and feelings. Wilson didnâ€™t try to make Penelope easier to understand â€” â€œthe opacity of Penelope,â€ as she puts it, is one of the aspects of the poem she wants to trouble readers and make them uncomfortable.

But small details can tell us something about even the most frustrating of characters. At one point in Book 21, Penelope unlocks the storeroom where Odysseus keeps his weapons â€” as Wilson writes in her translatorâ€™s note, this act sets in motion the slaughter of the suitors and the resolution of the poem. As she picks up the key, Homer describes her hand as pachus, or â€œthick.â€ â€œThere is a problem here,â€ Wilson writes, â€œsince in our culture, women are not supposed to have big, thick, or fat hands.â€ Translators have usually solved the problem by skipping the adjective, or putting in something more traditional â€” Fagles mentions Penelopeâ€™s â€œsteady hand.â€ Wilson, however, renders the moment this way: â€œHer muscular, firm hand/ picked up the ivory handle of the key.â€

â€œWeaving does in fact make a personâ€™s hands more muscular,â€ she writes. â€œI wanted to ensure that my translation, like the original, underlines Penelopeâ€™s physical competence, which marks her as a character who plays a crucial part in the action â€” whether or not she knows what she is doing.â€

Wilson does not give Penelope more agency or power than she has in the original poem, but she also does not take any of the queenâ€™s original power away by making descriptions of her conform to modern gender stereotypes.

â€œPart of fighting misogyny in the current world is having a really clear sense of what the structures of thought and the structures of society are that have enabled androcentrism in different cultures, including our own,â€ Wilson said, and the Odyssey, looked at in the right way, can help readers understand those structures more clearly. The poem offers a â€œdefense of a male dominant society, a defense of its own hero and his triumph over everybody else,â€ she said, â€œbut it also seems to provide these avenues for realizing whatâ€™s so horrible about this narrative, whatâ€™s missing about this narrative.â€

Recent events have led to a widespread debate over how audiences should consume the work of people we know to be abusers of women. This is intertwined with the question of how we should consume art that has racist, sexist, or otherwise bigoted elements. Often elided from this conversation is the fact that people of color and women of all races have been consuming racist and sexist art in America for generations (in many classes on Western literature, for instance, they have had little choice), and developing their own responses to it, responses that are often deeply nuanced.

Conservative talk of â€œspecial snowflakesâ€ demanding trigger warnings ignores the fact that people marginalized in the Western canon have long read literature from it in exactly the way Wilson describes: both as an endorsement of its authorâ€™s values, and as evidence of how horrible those values can be, and whom they leave out.

Wilsonâ€™s translation, then, is not a feminist version of the Odyssey. It is a version of the Odyssey that lays bare the morals of its time and place, and invites us to consider how different they are from our own, and how similar.
